Generation II.Gold: It spins string not only from its rear but also from its mouth. It is hard to tell which end is which.
Generation II.Silver: A single strand of a special string is endlessly spun out of its rear. The string leads back to its nest.
Generation II.Crystal: Rather than making a nest in one specific spot, it wanders in search of food after darkness falls.
Generation II.Stadium 2: It spins string not only from its rear but also from its mouth. It is hard to tell which end is which. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) A single strand of a special string is endlessly spun out of its rear. The string leads back to its nest. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Ariados's feet are tipped with tiny hooked claws that enable it to scuttle on ceilings and vertical walls. This Pokémon constricts the foe with thin and strong silk webbing.

Generation VII.Sun: There are some areas where people use the string Ariados spins for their own weaving. The resulting cloth is popular for its strength.
Generation VII.Moon: It spins thread from both its rear and its mouth. Then it wraps its prey up in thread and sips their bodily fluids at its leisure.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: Every night, it wanders around in search of prey, whose movements it restrains by spewing threads before it bites into them with its fangs.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: It spews threads from its mouth to catch its prey. When night falls, it leaves its web to go hunt aggressively.

Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It attaches silk to its prey and sets it free. Later, it tracks the silk to the prey and its friends.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It attaches silk to its prey and sets it free. Later, it tracks the silk to the prey and its friends.

Generation IX.Scarlet: A single strand of a special thread is endlessly spun out of its rear. The thread leads back to its nest.
Generation IX.Violet: It wanders in search of food after darkness falls, never nesting in a specific place.
